thread.title: Daily Telegraph July 3 1915

author: The Telegraph
title: Daily Telegraph July 3 1915
text: * Download the whole paper pdf & view * (31mb) Whilst the women’s page looked at fruit dishes, as “fruit helps to solve the housekeeper’s problem for the time being” and hints about “thrift at table” ( page 12 ), the issue of economising in food was also the subject of a lengthy article on the news pages. On page 10 we find one about the use of meat substitutes. Although “meat-eating is a habit which many English people may not find it easy to break away from” and “meat is far too nutritious a food to be dropped out of the national diet,” if people were “clearly told what other and equally nourishing foodstuffs are best suited to take their place” then perhaps it would help prevent a meat famine. However “people do not read … text-books” in which such information can be found, so Eustace Miles provides a helpful article for readers. However all is not totally what it might seem there. Whilst Miles, a former amateur world rackets and real tennis champion, gives what appears to be disinterested information, it is anything but. Miles was the proprietor of a health food shop and vegetarian restaurant, and was a crusader against a meat-rich diet, so he is clearly seizing the opportunity to utilise the necessities of wartime to promote his beliefs. Whilst he had a reputation by 1915, would all readers of the Telegraph been quite aware about the back story to this article? Also in today’s paper - “German insolence” on page 8 with a report of an audacious plan to use an island off Maine as a secret base for submarines - “With every step that our Allies recede the situation becomes more favourable for them,” is the latest spin on the Russian front – page 9 - A heavy battle is reported in the Baltic, although not many ships are actually mentioned – page 9 - Good news in Serbia as Granville Fortescue reports an abundant harvest and an improvement in sanitary conditions; “the only criticism I offer is that the latrines are highly unsanitary” – page 9 - The number of volunteers for munitions work now stands at a “satisfactory” 46,000 – page 9 - French successes are reported in the Dardanelles, whilst wounded soldiers are moved to northern Italy as temperatures in Egypt and Malta are too uncomfortably hot – page 9 - Flamethrowers are the latest reported German outrage – page 10 - Mrs Eric Pritchard condemns “grotesque” and “baroque” styles of headgear – page 12 Follow @telegraphnews
